reviewText:
Early Access Review

FTL meets XCOM.
Halcyon 6: Starbase Commander is a space strategy game from Massive Damage. Artefacts of an ancient, highly advanced civilization have been left scattered throughout occupied space. Halcyon 6, a derelict starbase, is one such artefact. Now in the hands of the Human Federation, Halcyon 6 is yours to command and restore, but with several factions around you, including a mysterious alien force, it’s going to be difficult to restore the base and protect nearby human settlements.

Visually, Halcyon 6 is fantastic. The pixel graphics are awesome, the menus and UI are great too. The design, though, is what really makes the visual side of things shine. The different factions are all well thought out and they look awesome, plus the different factions all have their own ships which are also very well designed.

Halcyon 6’s gameplay consists of several different elements which come together to create one game. Firstly, we have base building a la XCOM. You clear out rooms on the starbase which can then be used to house anything from power generators to ship hangars. Then we have a research tree similar to the one in Civilization: Beyond Earth (though Halcyon 6’s actually makes sense) through which you can unlock new ships, new rooms as well as improve fuel usage etc. Research is carried out instantly but it costs Materials and Dark Matter (two of the three resources in the game, they’re also used to build new ships and rooms though ships and rooms also require a certain number of humans to work on them, more humans can be found at colonies from which you can evacuate them). Fuel is the third resource which is consumed by fleets when you send them out. The game’s hints of FTL come from the different factions and the overall feel and the game’s design. The similarities also extend to the map which is a reasonably large portion of space filled with different sectors. When you send out a fleet and they move around the map is when time moves (though you can also unpause the game to hurry along any construction). Enemies and neutral or friendly ships can only move when time is unpaused so pausing the game can be used as a way to assess what’s going on and plan for any incoming attacks.

Combat is turn-based and can be up to 3v3 ships (though if you move to a sector with multiple groups on enemies you’ll have to fight one after the other). You have three different ship classes, each with a corresponding crew member class, there’s: Science, Engineering and Tactical. Each class has specific skills that you can unlock (and level up with your character) and each ship has three default skills as well which also improve when you level up. Skills usually inflict damage on a single target (though there are group attacks as well as buff skills for yourself/team) and they also inflict, exploit or inflict on-self different effects (usually a mixture of the three). Inflicting something generally deals damage over time or has some kind of status effect, for example you can disable a ship for a number of turns or damage the hull which deals a certain amount of damage over a number of turns. Other skills will then exploit these effects to create combos which deal considerably more damage than usual. For example, one of my Science ships can disable sensors which can then be exploited by my Tactical ships to deal considerably more damage than usual. To be effective in combat (and not get your ♥♥♥ handed to you) you’ll need to use these combos as much as possible. Inflict on-self will inflict a negative (occasionally positive) status effect on you. Combat can be very challenging so it’s important to make sure you’re prepared before you can and attack something, especially as you can’t save/quit once you’ve entered combat (though you can at any other time).

When you unlock a new crew member slot, you’ll be able to choose between the three classes for what you want. Each crew member has specific ship and ground combat skills that they can unlock later when they level up. Ground combat works in the same way as space combat and occurs when enemies are found after clearing out a room. Your crew members earn experience, and in turn level up, by surviving combat and they’ll sometimes earn bonuses such as a damage increase against certain factions as well.

Halycon 6 does have a story and it plays out in a similar way to XCOM. Like with XCOM, you can pick and choose when you want to progress with the story of the currently available first act (act two and three will be added later). The other factions will become more powerful over time but rushing in can be just as bad as taking too long. The story progresses through main missions and side missions. Side missions usually consist of simply protecting a human colony from a fleet of pirates or aliens but there are other tasks you’ll have to complete too, such as defending your starbase from an attacker (incredibly important since the humans on-board will gradually die while you’re being attacked). There are a couple of different storylines running through it so you may receive several main missions at once which usually require a couple of extra steps than a side mission. I won’t go into any more details to avoid spoilers though I will say that the first act already offers quite a lot which is obviously stretched out by the fact you can go through it at your own pace.

Completing missions awards you with valuable resources and this is one of the three ways you can get resources in the game. You can also visit human colonies that have resource extraction facilities (fuel, materials and dark matter) which will collect a certain amount of resources for you to collect, once you’ve collected them the colony will begin producing more. The starbase also produces resources though it does this incredibly slowly to begin with, you’ll need to complete research for this to be a viable means of collecting the amount of resources you need. Just like in XCOM and FTL, resource management is INCREDIBLY important. Run out of fuel and you can’t send your fleet out. Run out of dark matter, you can’t repair your ships. Run out of dark matter and materials you can’t build anything new. Run out of everything…well you’re just screwed.

Just a couple more things to wrap up. The game is pretty difficult to begin with and you’ll probably die quite quickly but once you’ve got the hang of things it’s a manageable difficulty. The soundtrack is excellent. Controls are basic, you don’t have to use anything other than your mouse but there are also helpful hotkeys. And lastly, despite being an Early Access game I didn’t encounter any bugs while playing it.

Verdict
Halcyon 6: Starbase Commander is an excellent, well designed, space strategy game with great gameplay, a good amount of content (with more to come) and an interesting story. If you’re a fan of strategy games you’ll definitely like this, even in its Early Access state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Halcyon 6 wasn't just going for a genre, it was going for ALL the genres, and the question becomes whether it can keep gamers entertained, or confuse the sweet internet JESUS out of them.  There are a huge amount of options, menus, choices, resource gathering, and of course combat in Halcyon 6, and in this review we'll be going over what we've currently been given as an Early Access Beta.  As usual we'll be looking at three categories in particular, Gameplay, Sound, and Look.

For those that would rather listen/watch an in-depth review rather than read it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ri-052Wmwt8

Gameplay: Halcyon 6 is a game that has a clear and defined attention to detail when it comes to the various game mechanics, and believe me, there are a LOT of game mechanics.  It's one thing when a game tries to do too many things at once, but when a game succeeds at doing most or even all of those things, THAT is the real triumph.  All of the things that I mentioned Halcyon 6 does it DOES do well.  Combat is filled with a measure of strategy, including a vulnerability exploration combo style system.  Exploration is fun, but somewhat limited in scope, allowing you to visit various planets and moons in an attempt to find additional aid, enemies, or resources.

Your team is built exclusively by you choosing from three random prospects whenever an open slot appears thanks to you increasing your fleet to three officers, or one of them meeting an untimely death.  You must utilize the resources you find to improve your technology, build additional ships, or upgrade the Halcyon 6 itself.  And the game itself gives you the opportunity to make choices, like allying with Pirates for, air quotes, “mutual gain” or canceling out a 2666 year loan by participating in a trial by combat (PICK THE TRIAL BY COMBAT).

Halcyon's only weakness is that the development team is still clearly measuring how to balance the progression of the game and the strength of the enemies the player has to deal with.  Since there's no difficulty button, several players have quickly found the game can go from tutorial mode to DIE ♥♥♥♥♥ DIE rather quickly.  Despite a few minor setbacks, the gameplay is not only solid but fun and varied, giving Halcyon a 9 out of 10.

Sound: The sound in Halcyon is superb, when it exists, which luckily is most of the time.  I only found a few small instances where ships or weapons didn't have accompanying sound effects, but the rest of the time the retro sci-fi music and the various blips and blasts of your offensive and defensive powers were a joy to listen to.  Halycon 6 remains classy and professional, while not letting go of that 1990's arcade style soundtrack.  There are no voice overs, but I wouldn't have expected any in a game like Halcyon 6, instead it's all about having satisfying effects for the players choices.  Right behind gameplay, Halcyon scores a 9 out of 10.

Look: Halcyon 6 is a pixel art style game, which means you're going to get your Chinese buffets worth of pixels.  If you go into the game understanding that this is the art style, you won't be disappointed.  The character designs are quite well done, and in some cases outright fantastic.  Even the effects can appear to jump off of the screen in some instances, showing Massive Damage definitely has a knack for working with this style of artwork.  Most importantly, while the game is pixel-art, you can actually see and understand what is happening.  An alien looks like an alien.  A space ship looks like a space ship, and more so, each races spaceships are different, which is a damn fine example to set, rather than cutting and pasting the same few models over and over.

You'll notice that in most scenes, such as combat scenes, the background not only varies, but is animated, which scores big points for Halcyon 6.  Even if it's just a few chunks of space rock floating to and fro, it adds so much compared to a simple, static background that remains completely stagnant.  Most importantly, the text and numbers are clear and easy to read, which has been a pet peeve of mine in some pixel-art style games.  One of the few immediate suggestions I would have is to make the health bars much more contrasted so that the overall amount of life the various combatants have is easier to see.  Outside of this, Halcyon 6 follows up with it's third straight 9 out of 10, giving it a total average score of 9 out of 10.

CHECK OUT THE FULL REVIEW ON ETHNOGRAPHIX:
https://ethnographix.squarespace.com/blog/2016/5/7/shohdeeze-halcyon-6

I had no idea Halcyon 6 was even in the making and, to be honest, I'm glad I didn't. Coming home from work to check the featured list and finding this elegant package waiting for me was a pure delight.

Halcyon 6 is the synthesis of titles such as FTL (though I don't entirely agree with that comparison given how different the mechanics are at present) and a three-party turn-based RPG such as Final Fantasy.

Alongside the combat mechanics which are beautifully rendered in a colorful and approachable palette is the strategy section between missions where you manufacture and make improvements to ships, your officers in command of said ships,the Halcyon 6 base itself, and patrol your local system keeping the peace.

It's a great example of how less is more. H6 uses a substantially less complicated interface and economy than that of it's 4x's counterparts to allow for accessible and genuinely fun gaming while maintaining a similar level of complexity and challenge. The art of managing your vessels in order to strike a balance between preservation of current resources while scouring potential planets for resources is challenging though and still in need of balancing.

The ships are a treat to behold and each one is borrows from awesomely cheesed up TV series such as Star Trek while being uniquely singular and beholden to the universe the game takes place in.

Interaction with other species is more on the comical side of things in the same way the ios game Star Command is (which was also a Kickstarter backed title). They share a few similarities in aesthetics but H6, despite the various comparisons with equally fantastic games such as FTL, manages to stand apart from such titles with a unique, fun, and stimulating degree of challenge and reward.

This was a hidden gem I only came across on accident but I think it deserves to be noticed. It is a great combination of many different ideas that come together to make a grand game. Building up your station is a fun thing to do but comes with dangers as you try to expand and find creatures living in your base. I lost many a cadet to those critters, good thing they are so expendable! Very hard to say what exactly I love the most when the whole package ended up being so fun.

The tactical combat is a welcome difference from all the extremely fast paced but boring combat of most space games. It is still very high energy as you struggle to fight against fleets stronger than you while trying to line up devastating combos that can obliterate a powerful vessle in two blows. My favorite being stunning the crew and then using suicide run to smash it to pieces. You feel strong when using your brain you defeat an enemy far stronger than you. Since this is a roguelike game expect that to be the case more often than not as they have some powerful fleets they will toss your way.

The star map is fun as it is frantic. Flying around space desperately trying to protect your stations from the aliens and deciding which ones just aren't possible to hold out any longer and evacuating them to save the crew. It is a tough decision because you will lose the resources it will generate but you get the crew of the station to build new ships and aid in defense. I had a lot of fun on my run plotting out paths that were the most efficient to pick up the resources while also obliterating any harrassing fleets trying to take out my infrastructure.

The side factions are also interesting. They seem to half want to kill you while on the other half looking to be your best pal. You'll have to discern for yourself who is truly at your side and who would love to punch a hole through your chest. My favorite being the pirates. They end up being much more than simple bandits that they first appear as you learn more about them and their internal struggles.

Couldn't recommend this game anymore than I can with just a thumbs up. It is well worth the money even in its limited early access state. Only one act out right now but for how fun it was, and that there is definitely replayability in decided who to help and who to blast into bits, its well worth the cash. Take a chance on this one, its worth it.

Early Access Review

Halcyon 6 is a turn-based strategy game heavily inspired by games like X-COM, Civilization, and FTL.

Federation gets wiped out by weird fleshy aliens and you are put in command of its last space station.
To survive, you'll need to do a whole lot of things in a turn-based manner.
After you'd hired a couple of officers and built a couple of ships for them, you can send them off into space.
You'll start with exploring the nearest planets and stations to gather resources. But just gathering won't be enough - you'll also need to protect those planets and stations from aliens who'll try to destroy them. You can, of course, always close them down and just rescue the crew, but then you won't get those precious resources.
The time on the map works the same way it did in XCOM games - enemies move whenever you do. So you'll have to decide very carefully on where to fly next.
Oh, and don't send them too far away - your space station will get attacked sooner rather than later and you will have to defend it!
And you'll also need to expand your station. First, clean out the rabble, then build something in new clean room (very much XCOM-like).
There's also a tech tree with a variety of unlocks and upgrades that include new rooms for the base and new ships. And more boring stuff like cheaper repairs, etc.
You'll also encounter different factions and races. They'll have quests and amusing dialogues. And you can kill them all if you so desire.

And yes, combat is going to be your primary activity.
It's also turn-based, but this time, it's closer to FTL (or maybe even Final Fantasy), rather than XCOM.
You'll have your fleet against enemy fleet, both can have up to 3 ships.
Ships take a turn to execute one action - shoot, buff, debuff, heal, etc.
Mostly, the battles are all about synergy between your ships skills - if you exploit weaknesses (debuffs) applied by previous ships, you can get insanely huge crits. And the longer you play, the more important that synergy becomes. I found it to be pretty cool.

From my time of playing it, I haven't encountered any serious issues.
There are some minor annoyances in UI (that no doubt will be ironed out eventually) and I also had a few glitches, but that's about it - pretty solid v0.1 :)

The enemies simply get larger and gain more HP so you just have to keep doing the same thing over and over for longer as time progresses!

During that time in which you cannot attack their spires from which they spawn, you will have to deal with endless waves of enemies that progressively get larger and stronger as I said above. Despite being in Early Access, I played this all weekend long and had to remind myself that it's not feature complete - because already there's a lot of fun to be had but there's even more awesomeness to come! MIND BLOWN!

Building up a fleet of ships which powers that compliment each other is fun - using those powers against any of the various enemy ships is satisfying!

The music is funky and the art-style is really nice with gory death-animations and explosions.

Everything in the game works really well (I encountered no bugs!)

I highly recommend this to title - the devs are doing a fantastic job (I guess the best evidence is the VERY POSITIVE Steam review rating).

Buy it.

Early Access Review

Combat and resource management/base building is surprisingly deep. Just keeping your galaxy pruned and healthy to keep that Dark Matter flowing is an engrossing job. Combat is good. Nearly every attack either can create a debuff or EXPLOIT a debuff, dissolving the debuff for a damage bonus. Many of the debuffs are quite helpful, so it creates an interesting game to keep or exploit. Team composition for land and space combat is everything, as is playing to your strengths. The best attacks may debuff the attacker as well. Be VERY careful you don't get exploited right back!

This reminds me of many a game with a main story, but enough side things to keep you well occupied without digging. I've not pushed through the main story, but if someone hadn't told me the game wasn't finished yet, I wouldn't have noticed. Has the potential to be a show stopper, but is fun as hell right now.

There is humour and fun to be had but also tense action when the enemy has the upper hand. I assume there will be lots of balancing but at the moment there is a steep rise in difficulty when the Cruul send a ship that is unbeatable unless you kill several other waves of enemies.

The ground based combat is on its first taste at the moment but that doesn't mean it is lacking in quality. It follows the same style as the space battles with abilities that cause statuses and abilities that take advantage of such abilities and it's all about exploiting these combinations to get success!

All in all a good fun game that I look forward to seeing how it progresses

What I like best about H6 is the tone. It's a mixture of horror and humor that is very well balanced to keep you laughing while at the same time just constantly uneasy. The character descriptions are especially good; whoever is writing those deserves a raise. Interacting with other factions diplomatically is a real treat. Do yourself a favor and really read all the text presented at you as you play. At any given point you realize you're in a blend of scifi parody and terrifying dystopia where technology is your last best hope for humanity but also incredibly dangerous. In that sense, I am reminded of XCOM, and the base-building and research gameplay reminds me of it as well. Other reviewers talking about FTL are right on the money, too, both in artistic style and game theme.

The story is compelling, but the game also has a wonderful soundtrack to really get you in the mood. It evokes a retro era while being unmistakably scifi with an epic scale. I'm a Kickstarter backer, and honestly the reward I am most looking forward to getting is a download of the soundtrack.

The game is currently in Early Access, so it should go without saying there are still bugs and balance issues, but the developers are addressing these quickly. I've been impressed with their professionalism and enthusiasm. The game is not yet content-complete, but it'll get there, and it promises to be highly moddable in the future. They've made a lot of tweaks to gameplay and the UI based on feedback, and I'm confident they're a talented and dedicated team.

I haven't talked a lot about gameplay here, but a lot of other reviewers have covered that already, and again the game is still being balanced so chances are whatever I'd say would be outdated by the time you read this. If it sounds like a game you might be interested in, you'll probably really love it. There are other games out there with similar gameplay elements, though I feel there's some useful innovations here. The quality of art, writing, and music are what really make this game shine.

As a Kickstarter Backer I just got my Beta access last week and i've spent a lot of time since then playing this game. It's great to see the game being pretty much exactly what they promised. But it's definitely still in beta. There are graphical glitches, minimal tutorials, insufficient tooltips, hotkeys aren't customizeable or even detailed anywhere I could find in the game and the ones I could figure out don't make a lot of sense to me, and game balance needs improvement. But I haven't found any genuine bugs in the mechanics of the game so far and that I'm happy about, it means they've built a solid framework for the game and just need to work out the details.

Getting through the first few story missions felt like climbing Everest...just completing the first step in the story took me more than an hour in my first game. The resources required to research and build the next tier of officer structure to unlock the 3rd officer feels extremely prohibitive, then building him/her a ship to join your fleet is another chore. I started a new game once I knew what to expect and it still took me almost 45minutes to get a 3rd officer and a ship for him, all the while fighting for my life against pirates and trying to respond to as many distress calls as I could to try to hold on to a few resource producing outposts and evacuate all the ones that were too far from the station for me to effectively protect so I could pad my crew on the station and not feel like a total failure when the Chruul eventually killed them. It took me nearly three hours to reach the target of the next stage of the storyline once I had my 3rd officer...sending a fleet of three ships to New Terra ended up feeling like a huge risk because it's so far away from the station and while the fleet is away you're defenseless. By the time they got home I had 2 enemy fleets sieging the station killing my crew in the bombardment.

It's been fun playing and I'm going to keep at it since i enjoy a challenge. The game is in a good spot for an Early Access release, but it does still need a lot of work.

This is just a personal opinion from my own experience. I only gave it a thumbs down because I was literally falling asleep from playing it. I may sound like a heretic since most people gave it a thumbs up. Perhaps it's the early alpha stage, but there is something about this game feels rather boring.

Graphic:
I love the art style. The presentation of the game is beautiful, and I can tell the developers gave a lot of loves and careful attentions to each pixel. The UI is simple to navigate and easy to the eyes. Job well done.

Story:
As the gaming age is constantly evolving, story writers are exploring non-linear storytelling style and there are untouched areas to be discover. Some game does it well, and some does it poorly. How does this game fair? At this alpha stage, it's rather boring. Yes, there are random encounters and events. However, just random event does not always make a good non-linear storytelling. For example in this game: some pirates appeared in a local sector and requires your decision to dispatch a fleet to eradicate them. However, there is no time restriction, so you are to do so whenever you are please. As an audience, there is no sense of urgency. My decision does not matter because I will eventually go fight them; it could be 2 days or 30 days later. These current random events are either fight these enemies or don't fight these enemies. I honestly hope there are further improvements. Give us the options to make a real decision and not a false illusion. Another example: we first encountered some pirates and they straight up declare war against Halcyon 6. The developer completely miss the opportunity to give these pirates a cunning personality trait such as persuasion, trading crews with you which later backstab your base and stealing tech from you, trading for their own profit gain, giving you a false sense of protection against the Cruul race, selling you faulty weaponries that you later discover during a combat and etc. These would broaden the non-linear story. But instead, we are the bad guys, therefore, we must fight. We then met the Cruul race and they straight up declare war against mankind. I can understand we need mortal enemies. But the current events are rather straight forward and boring when my decisions are either fight or don't fight; go there or don't go there. It feels so restricted.

Game play:
Base building can be fun. There is nothing wrong if this is done well. However, the 3 vs. 3 combat, some people will find this nostalgic and charming. Perhaps some younger audiences who didn't grow up with JRPG will find this refreshing. Very unfortunately, this is nothing new, nor unique, thus I find it outdated for anyone who played a fair amount of JRPG. I honestly think the developers restricted themselves on the current combat system. You probably saw many reviewers with a thumbs up saying the combat is repetitive. They are not joking. Just because we have fleet officers with different traits and status effects from ships, it doesn't always make the game complex, nor engaging.

Since the current story and gameplay both fail my expectancy. Reluctantly, I can't recommend it at this moment. However, it is only alpha, perhaps changes will be make and I may retract my statements.

Although the counter says otherwise, I've played about 12 hours of this game (most of my time was in offline mode). This game is a really cool blend of several ideas and mechanics that I find to be very enjoyable overall, but the combat had me so bored sometimes I almost quit on multiple occasions. Combat makes up most of what you'll be spending your time on, so it should be the most enjoyable part of the game, but in it's current state it's very repetitive and there's little strategy outside of buying ships and promoting officers that combo well together. Upgrading to a new tier of ships is a little lackluster as well, being more or less a stat upgrade + 1 or 2 more bland deal damage, inflict this, exploit this ability. On top of repeating the same combos with the same ships over and over again, some of the animations are very long and drag out the fairly long process of battle even longer. An option to skip animations or maybe a speed slider would already be a good start for the combat.

I know this is early access and that is exactly why I bring all of this up, I hope this can be addressed and improved because it's the only thing holding this game back from being a favorite. This game has huge potential and I want it to succeed. The art is amazing and the blend of different mechanics in the star base and on the map are cool and interesting. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Halcyon 6 has been a work in progress for some time, and it has much more to go, but don't let that discourage you from playing it.  The combat system is already fairly deep, and the simplicity of the mechanics* allows for significantly more, while the admittedly-derivative base-building system prevents it from overwhelming the player with its depth all at once.

*Attacks will both apply and exploit status effects.  This method makes combos the primary driving force during combat.  However, you control three ships at once, which decreases the inevitability of learning rote combos and, when that does occur, makes them three times as complex, as the process of setting up and knocking down enemies is no longer a simple back-and-forth repetition.

It's not perfect, though: content is slightly lacking at this point, which is to be expected from an early access game such as this; the progression and, by extension, fleet-building systems are very light; and the game can be quite frustrating.  However, the lost depth is made up through the combat system, which is likely to be a highlight of Massive Damage's entire catalog of games in the future.  I'd recommend it to most anyone I know; at least at a sale price, though it's worth full cost.
